Headline: Category Management & Procurement | Driving Efficiency in Retail, E-Commerce & FMCG
Comment:
AI can significantly enhance diagnostic accuracy, speed, and efficiency by analyzing complex data, identifying subtle anomalies in imaging, and even suggesting personalized treatment plans. This can reduce the workload of healthcare professionals, especially by automating routine or redundant tasks and streamlining processes.

However, the adoption of AI depends heavily on doctors‚Äô willingness to embrace new technology. Studies show that some physicians resist AI recommendations, especially when they conflict with their own judgment, often due to training gaps or concerns about professional credibility. This resistance can stem from traditional roles, perceived threats to expertise, or discomfort when patients arrive well-informed or with their own research.

Ultimately, for AI to reach its full potential in healthcare, there needs to be a cultural shift: doctors must be open to collaboration with AI, view it as a tool to augment rather than replace their expertise, and receive proper training to integrate AI insights into clinical decision-making. This partnership can lead to better patient outcomes and more human-centered care, provided both technology and mindsets evolve together.

Headline: Chief Operating Officer @ Tropilite Foods | Operational Excellence, Strategic Growth
Comment:
AI will certainly replace the kind of professionals ( including some kinds of doctors, lawyers, architects and many others ) who work at the back end -  with little human interaction. 

The current inflexion point in human history due to AI seems to be very different from earlier shifts - at no point of time during the earlier revolutions did the Agency pass from human hands. Now - it is a matter of time before it does. 

The development of AGI (only a matter of time) means we are possibly creating a species superior to Home Sapiens. And the second and third order effects of that will be dangerously unpredictable.

Headline: Leading Strategic Programs, Partnerships, and Growth across Adtech, Martech & Digital Ecosystem
Comment:
AI can stretch the general levels of expertise available across the board and make it consistent and repeatable. In expert hands, it can push boundaries, and then make that the new normal. It's this multiplier effect that is exciting and game changing. 

Quoting from personal experience, I got a scan done and the radiologist at the diagnostic lab graded a module as TIRADS-4. But when the FNAC doesn't reveal anything and I got the scan done again by an experienced doctor this time, it was reclassified as TIRADS-3. A shadow seen earlier was wrongly thought to be solid cyst particles and the experienced doctor could call out the difference. If this expertise is fed into the reinforced learning loop of An AI system, it could have interpreted the scan correctly, the first time, saving all the trouble, anxiety and money.

Headline: Healthcare Leader | Clinical Strategy & Operations | Digital Health & Innovation | HealthTech, Policy & Well-Being Expert
Comment:
Great post. As a doctor, my two bits is that accuracy alone isn‚Äôt enough, AI needs contextual judgment. If the training data reflects systemic gaps (like missed diagnoses in women or underrepresented populations), we risk scaling those inequities.
Trust comes not just from empathy, but from transparency and accountability. The question isn‚Äôt just can AI outperform us? but can it understand why we choose what we do?
That said, I also believe AI can be a powerful force for good, especially in resource-constrained settings. Supporting overburdened systems, aiding early screening in rural areas, or reducing admin load. These are places where AI can genuinely improve access and outcomes.
The key is designing it to amplify the human, not replace it.

Headline: Child health and maternal health - India
Comment:
Trust and empathy are all fine. But the REAL reason why AI will not replace a doctor is because you need HUMAN JUDGMENT for AI recommendations. And you need an expert (doctor) to exercise that judgment.

Teachers are a different issue altogether. For children, especially young children, human interaction and guidance are required for various reasons. A robotic solution will soon work for this, but society will insist on human connections for very young minds. For older children and adults, there is no reason for human teachers to continue to exist, once robotic systems improve some more.

Headline: TEDx Speaker, IRONMAN, LISTENER, PhD Scholar, COACH, Sales & Strategy Leader, Author,
Comment:
Tech is Best with its invisible, Beautiful line.
In any business, the tech is just a facilitator, not the core.

The fate of an EdTech does not depend on the UI quality or the speed at which it can dish out content or evaluate sheets. It's the back-end data, the content, the live or virtual tutor who has drafted and crafted the content and how optimised it is kept.

The success of a fintech does not lie in how fast it allows you to make and break ur investments. It's the financial advice that it can provide. The back-end team can raise the red flags, help you distinguish the benefits of bonds and mutual funds, and so on.

Similarly, AI is another tech, it's just an enabler, facilitator, accelerator in many cases, it's not meant to and WILL NOT be replacing core functions like doctors and educators.

Headline: AI/ML & Digital Health Leader | Transforming Care Delivery, Clinical Workflows & Hospital Operations | Product & Innovation | Narayana Health
Comment: The perspective on AI's healthcare impact lacks specificity. In a nation with a severe scarcity of doctors, and where access to highly skilled physicians is even more limited, AI offers a significant solution. It can begin by addressing the shortage through improved triaging and may eventually automate much of primary healthcare.

Headline: Executive Leadership | Enterprise AI Solutions | Strategic & Innovation Initiatives
Comment: In Indian context, the goal of making a billion people feel like they finally have access to Education & Healthcare is pretty much non-negotiable. I would extend this to the whole of 'Global South', which has been short on basic amenities. AI can and (ideally), should be used to augment & scale human capabilities to enable access to all. Because if the focus remains only on productivity & profitability, it is likely to lead to massive social disruptions.

Headline: Consultant maternofetal medicine
Comment:
Absolutely nailed it!
Great to know that what goes beyond treatment is appreciated in today's chaotic healthcare scenario. The core of healthcare is the silent support a doctor gives as a gentle touch on hand to say I'm there for you, an empathetic ear to hear the challenges a patient faces as a person, leaving aside the medical concerns. The extra touch that goes in is sharing lives as human beings. What a teacher can do cannot be replaced..
The inspiration and the motivation 
AI can't sure see your capabilities which a mentor can envision or a doctor who can connect with their patient at all levels.
It's a bond of a lifetime!
